verses.text: Then Solomon gathered all the elders of Israel, all the heads of the tribes, and the chiefs of the fathers’ houses of the people of Israel, before King Solomon in Jerusalem, to bring up the ark of the covenant of the LORD from the city of David, which is Zion.
verses.comment: Follows the narrative closely; Zion is clarified as the city of David.

verses.text: All the men of Israel assembled to King Solomon at the festival in the month of Ethanim, which is the seventh month.
verses.comment: Ethanim is preserved as the original month name, consistent with the Hebrew.

verses.text: All the elders of Israel came, and the priests took up the ark.
verses.comment: Faithfully rendered.

verses.text: They brought up the ark of the LORD, the Tent of Meeting, and all the holy vessels that were in the tent; the priests and the Levites brought them up.
verses.comment: Distinction between priests/Levites as in Hebrew.

verses.text: King Solomon and all the congregation of Israel, who had assembled before him, were with him before the ark, sacrificing so many sheep and cattle they could not be counted or numbered.
verses.comment: Preserves the overwhelming number of sacrifices theme.

verses.text: Then the priests brought the ark of the covenant of the LORD to its place, in the innermost room of the house, the Most Holy Place, under the wings of the cherubim.
verses.comment: Most Holy Place is commonly used for 'Holy of Holies.'

verses.text: For the cherubim spread out their wings over the place of the ark, so that the cherubim covered the ark and its poles from above.
verses.comment: Consistent with the description in Exodus.

verses.text: The poles were so long that the ends of the poles could be seen from the Holy Place in front of the inner sanctuary; but they could not be seen from outside. They are there to this day.
verses.comment: ‘To this day’ is retained as in the original.

verses.text: There was nothing in the ark except the two tablets of stone that Moses put there at Horeb, where the LORD made a covenant with the Israelites after they came out of the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Horeb is preserved as is.

verses.text: When the priests came out of the Holy Place, the cloud filled the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Closely matches Exodus account.

verses.text: So the priests could not stand to minister because of the cloud, for the glory of the LORD filled the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Glory of the LORD’ as in tradition.

verses.text: Then Solomon said, “The LORD has said that he would dwell in thick darkness.
verses.comment: ‘Thick darkness’—faithful to Hebrew ‘araphel’.

verses.text: I have surely built you a lofty house, a place for you to dwell in forever.”
verses.comment: ‘Lofty house’ keeps Hebrew ‘beith zebul’.

verses.text: Then the king turned around and blessed all the assembly of Israel, while all the assembly of Israel stood.
verses.comment: Faithful rendering, matches Hebrew word order.

verses.text: He said, “Blessed be the LORD, the God of Israel, who with his hand has fulfilled what he promised with his mouth to my father David, saying,
verses.comment: Maintains parallel between God’s promise and fulfillment.

verses.text: ‘Since the day I brought my people Israel out of Egypt, I have not chosen a city from any tribe of Israel to build a house for my Name to be there, but I have chosen David to be over my people Israel.’
verses.comment: ‘For my Name’—literal Hebrew.

verses.text: Now it was in the heart of David my father to build a house for the name of the LORD, the God of Israel.
verses.comment: Literal; 'in the heart' preserves idiom.

verses.text: But the LORD said to David my father, ‘You did well that it was in your heart to build a house for my Name.’
verses.comment: ‘Did well that it was in your heart’—literal rendering.

verses.text: Nevertheless, you will not build the house, but your son who will be born to you, he will build the house for my Name.’
verses.comment: ‘Your son who will be born to you’—direct translation.

verses.text: Now the LORD has fulfilled his word that he spoke; for I have risen in the place of David my father, and sit on the throne of Israel, as the LORD promised, and I have built the house for the name of the LORD, the God of Israel.
verses.comment: No significant change.

verses.text: And there I have made a place for the ark, in which is the covenant of the LORD, which he made with our fathers, when he brought them out of the land of Egypt.”
verses.comment: Literal phrasing.

verses.text: Then Solomon stood before the altar of the LORD in the presence of all the assembly of Israel and spread out his hands toward heaven.
verses.comment: Literal action described.

verses.text: He said, “O LORD, God of Israel, there is no God like you, in heaven above or on earth beneath, keeping covenant and steadfast love for your servants who walk before you with all their heart,
verses.comment: 'Steadfast love' for 'chesed', Hebrew idiom preserved.

verses.text: you have kept with your servant David my father what you declared to him. You spoke with your mouth, and with your hand have fulfilled it this day.
verses.comment: Literal word order is preserved.

verses.text: Now therefore, O LORD, God of Israel, keep for your servant David my father what you have promised him, saying, ‘You will not lack a man to sit before me on the throne of Israel, if only your sons pay close attention to their way, to walk before me as you have walked before me.’
verses.comment: 'Lack a man' is a direct translation of the Hebrew.

verses.text: Now therefore, O God of Israel, let your word that you spoke to your servant David my father be confirmed.
verses.comment: Simple and literal.

verses.text: But will God really dwell on the earth? Behold, heaven and the highest heaven cannot contain you; how much less this house that I have built!
verses.comment: ‘Highest heaven’ for ‘heaven of heavens’, preserving idiom.

verses.text: Yet have regard to the prayer of your servant and to his plea, O LORD my God, listening to the cry and to the prayer which your servant prays before you this day,
verses.comment: Literal wording.

verses.text: that your eyes may be open night and day toward this house, the place of which you have said, ‘My Name shall be there,’ that you may hear the prayer that your servant makes toward this place.
verses.comment: 'My Name shall be there' as in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: Listen to the plea of your servant and of your people Israel when they pray toward this place. And hear in heaven your dwelling place. And when you hear, forgive.
verses.comment: Sense and form preserved; last sentence is a literal plea.

verses.text: If someone sins against his neighbor, and he is made to take an oath and comes and swears an oath before your altar in this house,
verses.comment: Literal; follows legal formula.

verses.text: then hear in heaven, and act, and judge your servants, condemning the guilty by bringing his conduct on his own head, and justifying the righteous by rewarding him according to his righteousness.
verses.comment: 'Rewarding him according to his righteousness' is literal.

verses.text: When your people Israel are defeated before the enemy because they have sinned against you, and if they turn back to you and acknowledge your Name, and pray and plead with you in this house,
verses.comment: ‘Acknowledge your Name’—literal Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: then hear in heaven, and forgive the sin of your people Israel, and bring them back to the land that you gave to their fathers.
verses.comment: ‘Gave to their fathers’ is as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: When heaven is shut up and there is no rain because they have sinned against you, if they pray toward this place and acknowledge your Name and turn from their sin because you have afflicted them,
verses.comment: Literal.

verses.text: then hear in heaven and forgive the sin of your servants, your people Israel, and teach them the good way in which they should walk; and give rain upon your land, which you have given to your people as an inheritance.
verses.comment: Phrasing closely tracks the Hebrew.

verses.text: If there is famine in the land, if there is pestilence or blight or mildew, locust or caterpillar, if their enemy besieges them in their land at their gates, whatever plague, whatever sickness there is,
verses.comment: ‘Locust or caterpillar’ keeps specific insects as in Hebrew.

verses.text: whatever prayer, whatever plea is made by anyone or by all your people Israel, each knowing the affliction of his own heart and stretching out his hands toward this house,
verses.comment: 'Knowing the affliction of his own heart' is a direct translation.

verses.text: then hear in heaven your dwelling place and forgive, and act, and render to each whose heart you know— according to all his ways, for you, you alone, know the hearts of all mankind—
verses.comment: ‘Mankind’ is a faithful rendering of the Hebrew ‘sons of men.’

verses.text: so that they may fear you all the days that they live in the land that you gave to our fathers.
verses.comment: Direct translation.

verses.text: Moreover, concerning the foreigner, who is not of your people Israel but has come from a far country for your Name’s sake
verses.comment: ‘Foreigner’ is literal, not inclusive term.

verses.text: (for they shall hear of your great name, your mighty hand, and your outstretched arm), when he comes and prays toward this house,
verses.comment: Break for parenthesis, following Hebrew style.

verses.text: hear in heaven your dwelling place and do according to all for which the foreigner calls to you, so that all the peoples of the earth may know your name and fear you, as do your people Israel, and that they may know that this house that I have built is called by your Name.
verses.comment: Literal word order.

verses.text: If your people go out to battle against their enemy, by whatever way you send them, and they pray to the LORD toward the city you have chosen and the house that I have built for your Name,
verses.comment: Word order tracks original structure.

verses.text: then hear in heaven their prayer and their plea, and maintain their cause.
verses.comment: 'Maintain their cause' is a legal phrase in Hebrew.

verses.text: If they sin against you— for there is no one who does not sin— and you are angry with them and give them over to the enemy, so that they are carried away captive to the land of the enemy, far or near;
verses.comment: ‘There is no one who does not sin’ faithfully represents original.

verses.text: yet if they come to themselves in the land where they were carried captive, and repent and plead with you in the land of their captivity, saying, ‘We have sinned and acted perversely and wickedly,’
verses.comment: 'Come to themselves' as literal Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: if they turn back to you with all their heart and with all their soul in the land of their enemies who carried them captive, and pray to you toward their land which you gave to their fathers, the city which you have chosen, and the house that I have built for your Name,
verses.comment: Literal and phrasing kept.

verses.text: then hear in heaven your dwelling place their prayer and their plea, and maintain their cause,
verses.comment: No change.

verses.text: and forgive your people who have sinned against you, and all their transgressions which they have committed against you, and grant them compassion in the sight of those who carried them captive, so that they may have compassion on them.
verses.comment: Phrase ‘grant them compassion’ is faithful.

verses.text: For they are your people and your inheritance, which you brought out of Egypt, from the midst of the iron furnace.
verses.comment: ‘Iron furnace’ conveys oppression as per Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Let your eyes be open to the plea of your servant and to the plea of your people Israel, listening to them whenever they call to you.
verses.comment: ‘Whenever they call’ matches the Hebrew.

verses.text: For you set them apart from all the peoples of the earth to be your inheritance, as you declared through Moses your servant, when you brought our fathers out of Egypt, O Lord GOD.”
verses.comment: ‘Set them apart’ is a literal translation.

verses.text: Now as Solomon finished offering all this prayer and plea to the LORD, he arose from before the altar of the LORD, where he had knelt with his hands outstretched toward heaven.
verses.comment: Follows structure of original.

verses.text: He stood and blessed all the assembly of Israel with a loud voice, saying:
verses.comment: ‘With a loud voice’ as in traditional renderings.

verses.text: “Blessed be the LORD who has given rest to his people Israel, according to all that he promised. Not one word has failed of all his good promise, which he spoke by the hand of Moses his servant.
verses.comment: 'By the hand of Moses' is a literal phrase.

verses.text: The LORD our God be with us, as he was with our fathers. May he not leave us or forsake us,
verses.comment: Faithful to the original.

verses.text: that he may incline our hearts to him, to walk in all his ways and to keep his commandments, his statutes, and his rules, which he commanded our fathers.
verses.comment: 'Statutes and rules' as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Let these words of mine, which I have prayed before the LORD, be near to the LORD our God day and night, that he may uphold the cause of his servant and the cause of his people Israel, as each day requires,
verses.comment: 'As each day requires' is literal.

verses.text: so that all the peoples of the earth may know that the LORD is God; there is no other.
verses.comment: No deviation.

verses.text: Let your heart therefore be wholly devoted to the LORD our God, to walk in his statutes and to keep his commandments, as at this day.”
verses.comment: 'Wholly devoted' instead of 'perfect', to better reflect context.

verses.text: Then the king, and all Israel with him, offered sacrifices before the LORD.
verses.comment: Follows Hebrew verb order.

verses.text: Solomon offered as peace offerings to the LORD twenty-two thousand cattle and one hundred twenty thousand sheep. So the king and all the people of Israel dedicated the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Cattle' rather than 'oxen', literal modern usage.

verses.text: On the same day the king consecrated the center of the court that was before the house of the LORD, for there he offered the burnt offering, the grain offering, and the fat of the peace offerings, because the bronze altar that was before the LORD was too small to receive the burnt offering, the grain offering, and the fat of the peace offerings.
verses.comment: Literal with slight modernization of 'midst' to 'center.'

verses.text: So Solomon held the feast at that time, and all Israel with him, a great assembly from Lebo-hamath to the Brook of Egypt, before the LORD our God, for seven days and then for another seven days, fourteen days in all.
verses.comment: 'Lebo-hamath' and 'Brook of Egypt' are transliterated as in standard translations.

verses.text: On the eighth day he sent the people away. They blessed the king and went to their tents joyful and glad of heart for all the goodness that the LORD had shown to David his servant and to Israel his people.
verses.comment: 'Glad of heart' as in Hebrew idiom.
